questions.question_text:
An administrator at Cloud Kicks has been tasked by the compliance team to flag where sensitive information is stored in Salesforce.

What feature should the administrator use to fulfill this requirement?

discussion.content: he feature that the administrator should use to fulfill the requirement is Data Classification. The Data Classification feature allows organizations to create and apply labels to identify and protect sensitive data in Salesforce, such as personally identifiable information (PII) and financial data. Once data has been classified, it can be used to define policies for data protection, such as access controls, data retention, and data sharing.

questions.question_text:
DreamHouse Realty manages its accounts and contacts in Salesforce using a B2C account model. The business has requested that third-party loan advisors be tracked in Salesforce along with the customers they work with.

How should the administrator track third-party financial advisors and the customers they work with?

choices.C: Use a Hierarchical lookup on Contact to track loan advisors' customers.
choices.D: Create a Hierarchical lookup on Account to track loan advisors' customers.
choices.B: Use a B2B Account Model to track loan advisors' customers.
choices.A: Set up Contacts to Multiple Accounts for loan advisors.

discussion.content:
Since DreamHouse Realty uses a B2C account model, the best option to track third-party financial advisors and the customers they work with is to set up Contacts to Multiple Accounts for loan advisors. This will allow each loan advisor to be associated with multiple customer accounts, while still maintaining the B2C account model. Option A is, therefore, the correct answer.

Option B is not suitable because it suggests using a B2B account model, which is not the model that DreamHouse Realty is currently using. Option C and D are not suitable because they suggest using a hierarchical lookup, which is not necessary for this requirement and may complicate the data model unnecessarily.

questions.question_text:
AW Computing has a new requirement from its security team where audit information relating to an account must be recorded in a new custom object called Audit. Audit records need to be preserved for 10 years and only accessible by the audit team.

What relationship should be used to relate the Audit object to the Account object?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Every answer I've seen for this says A) but I don't know why. I'm of the view it should be a lookup, as audit records need to be kept no matter what happens to the account.

comments.content: I agree. Audits should be 'only accessible by the audit team', not by account owner
Additionally, the detail inherits the sharing settings of the master. Which we don't necessarily want in this case.

discussion.content: B: The recommended relationship type to relate the Audit object to the Account object would be a Lookup relationship. This is because a Lookup relationship allows a many-to-one relationship between two objects, where the Audit object can be linked to an Account record but multiple Audit records can be linked to the same Account record. Also, since the Audit records need to be preserved for 10 years and only accessible by the audit team, a Lookup relationship would provide flexibility in terms of record access and ownership. The audit team could be given access to view and manage the Audit records without necessarily having access to the related Account records.

questions.question_text:
An administrator notices that there are two account records in the system with the same name. A contact record with the same name is associated with each account.
Which set of steps should be taken to merge these accounts using the Salesforce merge feature?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
When merging accounts in Salesforce, if there are duplicate contacts associated with the accounts, Salesforce provides the option to merge those duplicate contacts at the same time. This is done by checking the option to merge related contacts when merging the accounts.

D. Merge the duplicate accounts and then merge the duplicate contacts using the Salesforce merge feature.

When using the Salesforce merge feature to merge duplicate records, it is generally recommended to merge the parent records first and then merge the child records. In this scenario, the duplicate account records should be merged first, and then the duplicate contact records can be merged.

choices.B: Merge the duplicate accounts and the duplicate contacts will be merged automatically
choices.A: Merge the duplicate contacts and then merge the duplicate accounts
choices.D: Merge the duplicate accounts and then merge the duplicate contacts
choices.C: Merge the duplicate accounts and check the box that optionally merges the duplicate contacts

C. Roll-up types include COUNT, SUM, and AVG.
D. Roll-up summary fields prevent the conversion of a master-detail relationship to a lookup.

choices.D: Roll-up summary fields prevent the conversion of a master-detail relationship to a lookup.
choices.B: Roll-up summary fields are created on the master side of a master-detail relationship.
